001/*  Written in 2016 by David Blackman and Sebastiano Vigna (vigna@acm.org)
002
003To the extent possible under law, the author has dedicated all copyright
004and related and neighboring rights to this software to the public domain
005worldwide. This software is distributed without any warranty.
006
007See <http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/>. */
008package squidpony.squidmath;
009
010import squidpony.StringKit;
011import squidpony.annotation.Beta;
012
013import java.io.Serializable;
014
015/**
016 * A Linear Feedback Shift Register that may be used like a StatefulRandomness but is not truly random. This has a
017 * period of (2 to the 64) minus 1, and is based on Wikipedia's code for a Galois LFSR but uses data from
018 * http://web.archive.org/web/20161007061934/http://courses.cse.tamu.edu/csce680/walker/lfsr_table.pdf .
019 * It is important to note that an LFSR will produce each number from 1 until its maximum exactly once before repeating,
020 * so this may be useful as a way of generating test data in an unpredictable order.
021 * @author Tommy Ettinger
022 */
023@Beta
024public class LFSR implements StatefulRandomness, Serializable {
025
026        private static final long DOUBLE_MASK = (1L << 53) - 1;
027    private static final double NORM_53 = 1. / (1L << 53);
028    private static final long FLOAT_MASK = (1L << 24) - 1;
029    private static final double NORM_24 = 1. / (1L << 24);
030
031        private static final long serialVersionUID = -2373549048478690398L;
032
033    public long state;
034
035    /**
036     * Creates a new generator seeded using Math.random.
037     */
038    public LFSR() {
039        this((long) (Math.random() * Long.MAX_VALUE));
040    }
041
042    public LFSR(final long seed) {
043        setState(seed);
044    }
045
046    public LFSR(final CharSequence seed)
047    {
048        this(CrossHash.hash64(seed));
049    }
050
051
052    @Override
053    public final int next(int bits) {
054        return (int)nextLong() >>> (32 - bits);
055    }
056
057    @Override
058    public final long nextLong() {
059        return state = (state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1L) & 0xD800000000000000L));
060    }
061
062    /**
063     * Produces a copy of this RandomnessSource that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the
064     * copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just needs to
065     * copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
066     *
067     * @return a copy of this RandomnessSource
068     */
069    @Override
070    public LFSR copy() {
071        return new LFSR(state);
072    }
073
074
075    /**
076     * Can return any int, positive or negative, of any size permissible in a 32-bit signed integer.
077     * @return any int, all 32 bits are random
078     */
079    public int nextInt() {
080        return (int)nextLong();
081    }
082
083    /**
084     * Exclusive on the outer bound; the inner bound is 0. The bound may be negative, which will produce a non-positive
085     * result.
086     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be positive or negative
087     * @return a random long between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
088     */
089    public int nextInt( final int bound ) {
090        return (int)((bound * (nextLong() & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31);
091    }
092    /**
093     * Inclusive lower, exclusive upper.
094     * @param inner the inner bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
095     * @param outer the outer bound, exclusive, should be positive, should usually be greater than inner
096     * @return a random int that may be equal to inner and will otherwise be between inner and outer
097     */
098    public int nextInt(final int inner, final int outer) {
099        return inner + nextInt(outer - inner);
100    }
101
102    /**
103     * Exclusive on the outer bound; the inner bound is 0. The bound may be negative, which will produce a non-positive
104     * result.
105     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be positive or negative
106     * @return a random long between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
107     */
108    public long nextLong(long bound) {
109        long rand = nextLong();
110        final long randLow = rand & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
111        final long boundLow = bound & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
112        rand >>>= 32;
113        bound >>= 32;
114        final long t = rand * boundLow + (randLow * boundLow >>> 32);
115        return rand * bound + (t >> 32) + (randLow * bound + (t & 0xFFFFFFFFL) >> 32);
116    }
117
118    /**
119     * Inclusive inner, exclusive outer; both inner and outer can be positive or negative.
120     * @param inner the inner bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
121     * @param outer the outer bound, exclusive, can be positive or negative and may be greater than or less than inner
122     * @return a random long that may be equal to inner and will otherwise be between inner and outer
123     */
124    public long nextLong(final long inner, final long outer) {
125        return inner + nextLong(outer - inner);
126    }
127
128    public double nextDouble() {
129        return (nextLong() & DOUBLE_MASK) * NORM_53;
130    }
131
132    public float nextFloat() {
133        return (float) ((nextLong() & FLOAT_MASK) * NORM_24);
134    }
135
136    public boolean nextBoolean() {
137        return nextLong() < 0L;
138    }
139
140    public void nextBytes(final byte[] bytes) {
141        int i = bytes.length, n = 0;
142        while (i != 0) {
143            n = Math.min(i, 8);
144            for (long bits = nextLong(); n-- != 0; bits >>>= 8) {
145                bytes[--i] = (byte) bits;
146            }
147        }
148    }
149
150    /**
151     * Get the current internal state of the StatefulRandomness as a long.
152     *
153     * @return the current internal state of this object.
154     */
155    @Override
156    public long getState() {
157        return state;
158    }
159
160    /**
161     * Sets the seed of this generator using one long, running that through LightRNG's algorithm twice to get the state.
162     * @param seed the number to use as the seed
163     */
164    public void setState(final long seed) {
165        if(seed == 0)
166            state = -1L;
167        else
168            state = seed;
169    }
170
171    @Override
172    public String toString() {
173        return "LFSR with state 0x" + StringKit.hex(state) + 'L';
174    }
175
176    @Override
177    public boolean equals(Object o) {
178        if (this == o) return true;
179        if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
180
181        LFSR lfsr = (LFSR) o;
182
183        return (state == lfsr.state);
184    }
185
186    @Override
187    public int hashCode() {
188        return (int) (state ^ (state >>> 32));
189    }
190
191    /**
192     * Gets the next number that an LFSR would produce using {@link #nextLong()} if its state was {@code state}.
193     * Does not allow state to be 0. Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you expect
194     * to call this again, such as with {@code (state = LFSR.determine(state))}, which will ensure the long-term
195     * properties of an LFSR hold up (such as having a period of ((2 to the 64) minus 1), or the guarantee that every
196     * number from 1 to ((2 to the 64) minus 1), inclusive on both, will be generated once per period).
197     * @param state any long other than 0
198     * @return the next long that a 64-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
199     */
200    public static long determine(final long state)
201    {
202        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1L) & 0xD800000000000000L);
203    }
204
205    /**
206     * Gets the next number from 1 to 255 that a different kind of LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
207     * Does not allow state to be 0. If given all byte values except 0 as arguments, will produce all ints 1-255.
208     * Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you expect to call this again, such as
209     * with {@code (state = LFSR.determineByte(state))}, which will ensure the long-term properties of an LFSR hold up
210     * (such as having a period of 255, or the guarantee that every number from 1 to 255, inclusive on both, will be
211     * generated once per period).
212     * @param state any byte other than 0
213     * @return the next int between 1 and 255 that an 8-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
214     */
215    public static int determineByte(final byte state)
216    {
217        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0xB8);
218    }
219
220    /**
221     * Gets the next number that a different kind of 32-bit LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
222     * Does not allow state to be 0. If given all int values except 0 as arguments, will produce all ints except 0.
223     * Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you expect to call this again, such as
224     * with {@code (state = LFSR.determineInt(state))}, which will ensure the long-term properties of an LFSR hold up
225     * (such as having a period of ((2 to the 32) minus 1), or the guarantee that every number from 1 to ((2 to the 32)
226     * minus 1), inclusive on both, will be generated once per period).
227     * @param state any long other than 0
228     * @return the next int that a 32-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
229     */
230    public static int determineInt(final int state)
231    {
232        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0xA3000000);
233    }
234
235    /**
236     * Gets the next positive long that a different kind of 63-bit LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
237     * Does not allow state to be 0 or negative. If given all positive long values (not including 0) as arguments, will
238     * produce all longs greater than 0. Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you
239     * expect to call this again, such as with {@code (state = LFSR.determinePositiveLong(state))}, which will ensure
240     * the long-term properties of an LFSR hold up (such as having a period of ((2 to the 63) minus 1), or the guarantee
241     * that every number from 1 to ((2 to the 63) minus 1), inclusive on both, will be generated once per period).
242     * @param state any positive long, not including 0
243     * @return the next int that a 63-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
244     */
245    public static long determinePositiveLong(final long state)
246    {
247        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1L) & 0x6000000000000000L);
248    }
249
250    /**
251     * Gets the next positive int that a different kind of 31-bit LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
252     * Does not allow state to be 0 or negative. If given all positive int values (not including 0) as arguments, will
253     * produce all ints greater than 0. Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to state if you
254     * expect to call this again, such as with {@code (state = LFSR.determinePositiveInt(state))}, which will ensure the
255     * long-term properties of an LFSR hold up (such as having a period of ((2 to the 31) minus 1), or the guarantee
256     * that every number from 1 to ((2 to the 31) minus 1), inclusive on both, will be generated once per period).
257     * <br>
258     * A potential benefit of using this particular LFSR type is that the period is a prime number, 2147483647; this can
259     * sometimes be relevant if you simultaneously get pseudo-random numbers from sources of randomness with different
260     * periods that are "relatively co-prime" (that is, they share no common factors other than 1). This case lengthens
261     * the total period of the combined generators significantly, generally multiplying the periods together to get the
262     * combined period, as opposed to other cases that may simply add them together.
263     * @param state any positive int, not including 0
264     * @return the next int that a 31-bit LFSR would produce with the given state
265     */
266    public static int determinePositiveInt(final int state)
267    {
268        return state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0x48000000);
269    }
270
271    /**
272     * Gets the next int that a different kind of LFSR would produce if its state was {@code state}.
273     * Does not allow state to be {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}, nor will this produce a result of {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}
274     * (as long as {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE} was not the input). If given all int values except
275     * {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE} as arguments, will produce all ints in the range {@code [-2147483647,2147483647]},
276     * including 0 but not -2147483648 (the minimum int). Strongly consider using the result of this and assigning it to
277     * state if you expect to call this again, such as with {@code (state = LFSR.determineIntSymmetrical(state))}, which
278     * will ensure the long-term properties of an LFSR hold up (such as having a period of ((2 to the 32) minus 1), or
279     * the guarantee that every int except {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE} will be generated once per period).
280     * <br>
281     * This is called Symmetrical because it produces the same amount of positive and negative numbers, instead of the
282     * normal generation of more negative ones (due to how ints are represented, the min value is always further from 0
283     * than the max value for any signed integer type).
284     * @param state any int other than -2147483648 (0x80000000), which is {@link Integer#MIN_VALUE}; can produce 0
285     * @return the next int other than -2147483648 that an LFSR would produce with the given state
286     */
287    public static int determineIntSymmetrical(final int state)
288    {
289        return ((state ^ 0x80000000) >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0xA3000000));
290    }
291
292    /**
293     * Gets the next number that an LFSR would produce using {@link #nextInt(int)} if its state was {@code state} and
294     * {@code bound} was passed to nextInt(). Does not allow state to be 0, but bound can be negative, which causes this
295     * not to produce positive numbers. This method is very predictable and its use is not encouraged; prefer using
296     * {@link #determineBounded(int, int)}.
297     * @param state any long other than 0
298     * @param bound the exclusive bound on the result as an int; does better if the bound is not too high (below 10000?)
299     * @return the next value that {@link LFSR#determine(long)} would produce with the given state, but limited to bound; can return 0
300     */
301    public static int determineBounded(final long state, final int bound)
302    {
303        return (int)((bound * (state >>> 1 & 0xFFFFFFFFL)) >> 32);
304    }
305    /**
306     * Gets an int using {@link #determineInt(int)} and bounds it to fit between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive).
307     * Does not allow state to be 0, but bound can be negative, which causes this not to produce positive numbers.
308     * @param state any int other than 0
309     * @param bound the exclusive bound on the result as an int; does better if the bound is not too high (below 10000?)
310     * @return the next int that {@link LFSR#determineInt(int)} would produce with the given state, but limited to bound; can return 0
311     */
312    public static int determineBounded(final int state, final int bound)
313    {
314        return (int)((bound * ((state >>> 1 ^ (-(state & 1) & 0xA3000000)) & 0xFFFFFFFFL)) >> 32);
315    }
316}
